metadata.title: Hierarchical Aerographite Nano-Microtubular Tetrapodal Networks based Electrodes as Lightweight Supercapacitor

sections.text:
microstructured materials as electrodes due to their relatively low-cost production, abundance, large surface area, high chemical stability, wide operating temperature range, and ease of processing including many more excellent features. The nanostructured carbon materials usually offer various micro-textures due to their varying degrees of graphitisation, a rich variety in terms of dimensionality as well as morphologies, extremely large surface accessibility and high electrical conductivity, etc. The possibilities of activating them by chemical and physical methods allow these materials to be produced with further higher surface area and controlled distribution of pores from nanoscale upto macroscopic dimensions, which actually play the most crucial role towards construction of the efficient
electrode/electrolyte interfaces for capacitive processes in energy storage applications. Development of new carbon materials with extremely high surface areas could exhibit significant potential in this context and motivated by this in present work, we report for the first time the utilization of ultralight and extremely porous nano-microtubular Aerographite tetrapodal network as a functional interface to probe the electrochemical properties for capacitive energy storage. A simple and robust electrode fabrication strategy based on surface functionalized Aerographite with optimum porosity leads to significantly high specific capacitance (640 F/g) with high energy (14.2 Wh/kg) and power densities (9.67x103 W/kg) which has been discussed in detail.
1. Introduction
The new and upcoming nano- and microstructured carbon materials with extremely high surface are considered as the prospective electrodes for industrial scale capacitive processes.[1-4] Carbon materials mainly store charges in an electrochemical double-layer formed at the interface between the electrode and the electrolyte.[5] Therefore, the capacitance predominantly depends on the surface area accessible to the electrolyte ions [6]. The important factors influencing their electrochemical performance are surface area, pore size and morphology, electrical conductivity and surface functionality.[7-8] New carbon materials with larger surface areas also exhibit higher capability for charge accumulation at the electrode/electrolyte interface.[9] In addition to the high surface area and appropriate pore size, surface functionalization has also been considered to be an effective way to improve the capacitance of different structured carbon materials.[10] It is believed that surface functional groups or heteroatoms can help the adsorption of ions and then can improve the hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity of the carbon materials, leading to enhanced wettability and thereby facilitating the easy and rapid electrolyte ion transports within the microscopic
pores.[11] At the same time, the presence of functional groups on the surface of carbonaceous materials may induce Faradaic redox reactions, leading to additional 5-10% increase in the total capacitance.[12-13] So far, different materials such as various carbon materials, mixed metal oxides and conducting polymers have been used as supercapacitor electrode materials but this field has been sincerely looking for novel carbon materials with unique microstructural features.[14] Particularly, carbon, in its various forms, has already been utilized as electrode materials for supercapacitor, aiming at high specific capacitance together with enhanced power density.[15] Although porous carbon materials exhibit high specific surface area, the low electrical conductivity of porous carbon materials is limiting its application in high power density supercapacitors.[16-18] Carbon nanotubes (CNTs), with excellent electrical conductivity and high surface area, have been utilized for supercapacitor fabrications.[19-20] However, CNT-based supercapacitors could not deliver the expected performance and one possible reason is probably due to the observed contact resistance between the electrode and the current collector.[21] Hence, many studies have focused on the morphology of the carbon materials to boost the performance of the capacitor such as growing CNTs directly on bulk metals to eliminate the contact resistance.[22] Graphene, on the other hand, with one-atom thick layer of two dimensional (2D) structure, has also emerged due to its high surface area, conductivity and stability.[23] However, optimizing the electrochemical performance of graphene based electrode materials still remain challenging, because, the electrochemically active surface area is always smaller than the predicted from the ultrahigh surface area of ideal graphene.[12] This is mainly attributed to the facile aggregation/restacking of graphene sheets caused by the strong van der Waals interaction during the electrode fabrication process.[24] Furthermore, the low conductivity of graphenebased electrodes relative to that of ideal graphene also limits the electrochemical performance of graphene-based electrodes.[18, 25] To overcome these technical challenges, there is
increasing demand for a practical solution to develop more efficient carbon materials and their energy storage devices.
Recently a a new type of carbon-based nano- and microtubular network, i.e.,
Aerographite (AG), is emerged as an appropriate alternative material, because of it's extremely low density hollow-framework (density < 0.2 Âµg/cm 3 ), with closed graphitic tubular shells and improved electrical conductivity (~10.0 S/m), highly flexible and an extremely robust material able to withstand the strong mechanical deformations and accelerations.[26-28] Despite its low density, it can be fabricated in various macroscopic shapes in the order of several cubic centimetres. The synthesised Aerographite material exhibits a well interconnected network of hollow nano-microtubular tetrapodal architectures with microscopic tube diameter and nanoscopic wall thicknesses (10-20 nm).[26] Because of hollow nature of the tubes, Aerographite material exhibits very high surface area and extremely large free volume to make the surface accessible which is indeed an asset for various applications ranging from supercapacitors to electrocatalyts.[26-27, 29-31] Growth of Aerographite nano-microtubular network material is a single step process in the chemical vapour deposition (CVD) and is mainly achieved via direct conversion of three dimensional porous sacrificial templates of tetrapodal zinc oxide (ZnO).[26, 32] Therefore it has got the flexibility of tailoring the bulk parameter like surface area and free volume by the assembly of the template. The surface morphology (rough or smooth), surface chemistry (sp 2 or sp 3 hybridizations) i.e., from graphitic to glass-like pyrolytic carbon, etc., can be achieved just by varying the growth parameters in the CVD process and hence appropriate properties for multifunctional utilizations. The hollow graphitic nano-microtubes in the Aerographite tabular networks exhibit several nanoscopic pores in the walls which again include additional surface contributions to the entire network and hence the resultant surface area of Aerographite is rather much higher. Availability of such three dimensional (3D) nano-microtubular
architecture with high surface as well as nanopores allows easy accessibility for chemical species to react with the Aerographite surface. In contrast to other carbon-based nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes and graphene, Aerographite exhibits smooth fracture behaviour with an ultimate tensile strength in the range of 1 to 100 kPa, which is higher than its counterparts.[26, 28, 32] All these outstanding physical and chemical features make Aerographite an ideal candidate to be explored for energy storage applications. Here, we report for the first time, the use of carbon based Aerographite as a novel electro-interface that can overcome several limitations which have been faced by previous carbon-based interfaces for supercapacitor applications.
2. Materials and Methods 2.1. Synthesis of Aerographite tetrapodal networks
The carbon based nano-microtubular tetrapodal Aerographite networks were prepared by the direct conversion of porous sacrificial zinc oxide (ZnO) 3D templates with density ~ 0.3 g/cm 3 (growth from flame transport synthesis process[32]) in a chemical vapour deposition (CVD) process in presence of hydrogen and toluene precursor gasses.[26, 31] Just for elaboration, the growth strategy of carbon based Aerographite material is demonstrated in Figure 1. The porous (~92%) interconnected 3D networks from ZnO structures (obtained from flame transport synthesis process (Figure 1A) are used as sacrificial templates in CVD chamber where they have been converted into AG network (Figure 1B) in a single step CVD conversion process in presence of reactant gases. During conversion, Aerographite structures retain the initial ZnO template architecture which is tetrapodal mainly. The Aerographite tetrapods are hollow from inside with nano-microtubular arm morphology[27, 31] in contrast to initial ZnO template which solid.[32] The conversion process takes place via selective removal of ZnO followed by simultaneous deposition of Carbon in a belt like growth
process[26] as schematically shown in Figure 1C. The conversion process of ZnO tetrapods into AG tetrapods during CVD growth process is demonstrated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images in Figure 1D-F respectively where Figure 1D and Figure 1E correspond to partially and almost converted ZnO tetrapod into Aerographite respectively (dark contrast stands for ZnO, however bright is for Aerographite). The completely converted ZnO network into Aerographite material is represented by typical SEM image in Figure 1F confirming the retention of tetrapodal morphology from initial template however, the AG tetrapods are slightly crumbled which is mainly due to their hollow nano-microtubular morphology. Further representative images from sacrificial ZnO templates and Aerographite materials are given in supplementary information (Figure S1). Detailed structural and high resolution transmission electron studies on ZnO and Aerographite material are presented supplementary information Figures S2 and S3 respectively and further detailed informations about Aerographite can be found in already existing works [26-27, 29-30] and the motivation of present work is to explore the capabilities of Aerographite material towards energy storage applications which is described in next sections.
2.2. Surface modification of Aerographite material
In a typical preparation of Aerographite based structures, 1.0 mg of as-synthesised Aerographite was dispersed in 5 mL of 0.1 M sodium dodecyl benzene sulphonate (SDBS) aqueous solution. The reaction mixture was sonicated for 1 h, and mixed for 3 h at room temperature (RT) under mild stirring. After 3 h of reaction time, the resulting suspension was subjected to three cycles of centrifugation to isolate surface-capped Aerographite structures. The Aerographite specimens were carefully washed with distilled water to remove the excess SDBS and afterwards drying was done at room temperature.
2.3.Fabrication of AG based electrode interface
Prior to immobilisation of self-assembled Aerographite-based bioconjugate, the glassy carbon electrode (GCE) surface was carefully polished with 1, 0.3, and 0.5 Âµm of Î±-alumina slurry successively and washed with deionised water. In order to obtain the functionalised electrode surface for further immobilisations, the electrode surface was first oxidised in PBS (pH 7.4) by applying a 1.0 V DC potential for 5 min. Then the surface was activated by EDC/NHS solution ([EDC] = [NHS] = 5 mM) which was prepared with cold water and then equilibrated for 2 h at room temperature.[33-34] The resulting succinimidyl ester-terminated surface was rinsed with water and dried under a stream of nitrogen. Then Aerographite-based assembly (50 ÂµL) was dropped onto activated GCE and dried for overnight.
2.4. Electrochemical measurements
Electrochemical measurements including cycling voltammetry, amperometry and constant
current charge-discharge measurements were carried out with an Ivium Stat.XR electrochemical analyser (Eindoven, Netherlands), the impedance measurements were carried out with an Autolab potentiostat-galvanostat workstation (Utrecht, Netherlands). A threeelectrode cell with glassy carbon working electrode, having 0.07 cm 2 surface area, platinum wire auxiliary and Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) reference electrodes were used in the voltammetric measurements. All electrochemical capacitor tests were perfomed in 1 M H2SO4 aqueous solution as electrolyte. A gravimetric capacitance was calculated from constant current chargeâdischarge curves in a three-electrode cell.
3. Results and discussion
Architectural intactness is very important requirement for any complex nanostructure which is going to be utilized for any application because it's surface has to be exposed with some
external identities, for example modification of AG with SDBS in present case. The morphological evolution of the Aerographite material after surface modification with SDBS was observed using SEM and corresponding morphologies at increasing magnifications are presented in Figure 2A-C. It can be clearly seen that during the surface modification, the Aerographite tetrapodal network retains its structural integrity in the form of a hollow nanomicrotubular morphology with crumbled tube surfaces leading to high surface-to-volume ratio. The structural retention of AG network after modification with SDBS was also confirmed by Raman spectroscopy investigations (Supplementary Information Figure S4). The typical electrode arrangement based on Aerographite material on glassy carbon electrode (GCE) is shown by schematic in Figure 2D which was used for all the cyclic voltammetry studies.
To evaluate performance characteristics of electrochemical capacitors, there are three
essential parameters, including cell (total) capacitance (CT), operating voltage (Vo), and equivalent series resistance (ESR). They are usually used to assess their energy and power performances as long as the material, fabrication method and cell design are fixed. There are various instruments and test methods that have been used to characterize the performance of electrochemical capacitors.[9] Cyclic voltammetry (CV), constant current charge-discharge (CCCD), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) are the most commonly employed techniques. With these techniques, one can measure fundamental parameters; voltage, current and time and yield some key metrics for electrochemical capacitors including the capacitance, equivalent series resistance, operating voltages, the time constant, energy and power densities.
First, the cyclic voltammetry measurements were performed in a three-electrode
system using a 1M H2SO4 aqueous electrolyte to understand the electrochemical behaviours
of Aerographite electrode. In general, CV testing applies a linearly changed electrical potential between reference and working electrode. The speed of the potential change in mV/s is designated as scan rate, and the range of potential change is called the potential window. The instantaneous current during the cathodic and anodic sweeps is recorded to characterise the electrochemical reactions involved.[35] In order to examine the charge storage mechanisms of electrochemical capacitors where electrical double-layer (EDLC) and faradaic (pseudocapacitance-PC) types, CV testing is regarded as the most suitable approach. Figure 3A shows scan rate normalized cyclic voltammetry measurement represented in terms of specific capacitance in y-axis (F/g) and voltage in x-axis (V). The results were obtained by normalizing cyclic voltammetry curves (Figure S5a, Supporting Information) with scan rate, and then divided to mass of electrode material employed. It is important to note that the shape of all CV curves show prominent redox peaks overlaid on top of substantial EDLC components, arising from the redox reactions of the oxygen functionalities. As shown in Figure 3A, the redox peaks which lead to a remarkable faradaic capacitance, come from redox reactions (a faradaic process) of oxygenated groups on the surface of Aerographite. Thus, the presence surface functional groups on Aerographite appear to be an effective way of improving an electrode surface. The Figure S5b (Supporting Information) shows that, the presence of surface functional groups induce faradaic reactions and cell capacitances (areas under each section) increase 50%. The results indicate that present Aerographite material shows hybrid capacitive behaviour, bearing double layer and pseudocapacitance simultaneously. However, these surface functional groups seem not to exhibit long-term stability. In Figure 3A, the cyclic stability of Aerographite electrode was tested in 50 mV/s scan rate which shows that the faradaic peaks started to diminish by around 30% after 1000 runs. However, the double layer capacitance in this voltage range (0.4-0.7 V) does not change.
Constant current charge-discharge (CCCD) testing is considered the most commonly
used, accurate and versatile technique to characterize electrochemical capacitors under constant current.[36] The measurements are usually conducted by repetitive chargingdischarging of the capacitor device or the working electrode at a constant current. All three key parameters including CT, RES, Vo of capacitor devices and other complementary information such as time constant, power and energy densities can be calculated from CCCD measurement.
The Figure 3B shows constant current charge-discharge curves at three different
current densities. The specific capacitance was calculated from discharge curves with values of 640 F/g obtained at current densities of 1.0 A/g after considering the voltage drop (IRdrop) based on detailed description in Figure S6a-b (Supporting Information) and Equation 1;[9]

where Idis , âtnet , âVnet , and m are the applied discharge current, net discharge time, net voltage change, and the mass of active material, respectively. The equivalent series resistance (ESR) was also calculated based on CCCD curve (Figure S6b) in IR-drop region by dividing voltage drop to constant current. The result shows that at the initiation of the discharge is 0.002 V (IR-drop) for same current density, suggesting a relatively low equivalent series
resistance (82 ) in the test cell.
Detailed cyclic voltammetry and charge-discharge stability tests for several cycles
(upto 1000) were performed and corresponding results are presented in Figure 4 (A-D). The measurements of capacitance retention were carried out in constant current charge-discharge at the current density 50 A/g, and in the cyclic voltammetry at 50 mV/s scan rate for 1000 runs for both cases. The capacitance values form CCCD measurements retain 92% and 81%
from CV measurement after 1000 runs from the first values. The Figure 4D shows dependence of specific capacitance to discharge current density from 0.05 A/g to 20 A/g. The results show that cell capacitance decreases when the discharge current density is increased. At the largest discharge current density, the capacitance retention is still as high as 70% for overall capacitance at lowest current density.
Another useful technique to calculate key metrics of electrochemical capacitor is
electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. EIS technique allows us to measure the impedance of a power cell as a function of frequency by applying a low-amplitude alternative voltage superimposed on a steady-state potential. Once the EIS experiment is complete, the data at each measured frequency described in four different components including the real and imaginary components of voltage (Eâ and Eââ), the real and imaginary components of current (Iâ and Iââ). From these components, one can easily compute the phase shift (Q) and the total impedance for each frequency.[35] The results are mainly expressed graphically in Bode plot to demonstrate the cell response between the phase angle and frequency, and in Nyquist plot to show the imaginary and real parts of the cell impedances on a complex plane. Based on Bode and Nyquist plots, one can calculate capacitance and ESR, respectively.[37-38] The Figure 5A shows a Bode plot for the same data pictured in the Nyquist plot (Figure 5B) in open circuit potential. Generally, Bode plot allows us to examine the absolute impedance, |Z|, as calculated by Equation 2 and phase shift, Q, of the impedance, each as a function of frequency by Equation 3;[35]
   22 '''|Z| ZZ  (2)
'/''tan ZZ (3)
where Zâ and Zââ represent real and imaginary part of impedance in both equations, respectively. Since the frequency is involved in Bode plot as a one of the axis, one can understand dependency of impedance to frequency. The Bode plot also allows yield the value
of polarization resistance (Rp) and ohmic resistance (RÎ©). Usually, the ohmic resistance dominates the impedance and can be calculated directly from high frequency horizontal plateau. However, at the lowest frequencies, polarization resistance also plays an important role and Rp + RÎ© can be calculated form low frequency horizontal plateau. In ideal case, Bode plot should be a straight line with a slope of -1 at the intermediate frequencies. The extrapolation of the line in Bode plot yields the value of cell capacitance. Based on the description above, we calculated cell capacitance as 0.062 F. A frequency response analysis of the frequency range from 10 kHz to 10 mHz yields Nyquist plot shown in Figure 5B. The plot features a vertical curve, indicating a nearly ideal capacitive behaviour of the cell. From the inset of Figure 5B, a transition between resistance capacitance semicircle and the migration of the electrolyte was determined by extrapolating the half-semicircle and it gives a resistance of about 26 Î©. The Bode and the Nyquist plots of same Aerographite electrodes were also examined in different applied voltage and the results were shown in Figure S7a-d (Supporting Information).
The Figure 6 shows the diagram of a self-discharge measurement of Aerographite
electrode. Here, the electrode was first charged to 0.8 V and the potential was held for 4 days and open-circuit potential was measured and recorded versus time to calculate leakage current (Ileakage). The voltage change for this electrode was less than 30 mV after 10 minutes. Then, the leakage current calculated by using Equation 4, and it was found to be 4.16 ÂµA.

Another important key parameter for electrochemical capacitors is time constant (Ï). The time constant is a measure of responsiveness of the device and can be calculated by using Equation 5.

where CT, and ESR represent cell capacitance and equivalent series resistance obtained by CCCD measurement and IR-drop calculation based on Figure 3B and Figure S6 (Supporting Information). The time constant value of Aerographite electrode is calculated to be 2.62 s.
One of the most important metrics for all types of energy devices are power and
energy density, directly relevant to end applications and of the key metrics to evaluate the performance. The most common calculation method for the maximum power density is shown in Equation 6.

Where Vo, m and ESR represent operating voltage, amount of materials used and equivalent series resistance obtain by CCCD technique. The power density of Aerographite electrode is calculated to be 9.75x10 3 W/kg. The energy stored or released from electrochemical capacitor can be evaluated through the integration of the working diagram obtained by CCCD curve (Figure S8, Supporting Information). Here, stored energy can be obtained from the charging curve, and deliverable energy from discharging curve. The ratio of these two regions gives energy efficiency of the electrochemical capacitor. For EDLC, the geometrical area of discharging triangle gives energy density however when hybrid capacitor is employed, one should use the integration of discharging curve based on Equation 7.

Where Vo, m and I represent operating voltage, amount of materials used and constant current used in CCCD measurement. In the equation, dividing by 3600 converts energy density from Joule to wattâhour. Based on Equation 7, the energy density of Aerographite electrode is calculated to be 14.2 Wh/kg. Figure 6B compares the energy and power density values
previously prepared electrodes or devices and Aerographite based electrodes expressed in Ragone Plot format which suggest that such highly interconnected ultralight 3D carbon based Aerographite nano-microtubular architecture could play significant potential role in milieu of its applications towards supercapacitor and energy storage devices.
4. Conclusions
In summary, for the first time we have demonstrated the fabrication of a high-performance Aerographite-based electrode material, as a simple-to-use, inexpensive and high order supercapacitor device arrangement. Moreover, the material proves to be highly sensitive, selective and stable. The results demonstrate that macropores and micropores are both generated during the synthesis of Aerographite material, which easily facilitates the addition of redox active functional groups. The integration of porous structures and functional groups help towards increasing the specific capacitances. Overall, this work presents fabrication of unique Aerographite based electrodes which shows substantially improved capacitive performances. This new generation of light-weight hybrid electrode carbon nanomaterials could significantly accelerate the developments in the field of energy storage and provide versatile platforms for high-performance energy devices.

sections.heading: Highlights
sections.text:
1. We report for the first time the utilization of nano to macrotubular newtwork of
Aerographite as a functional interface to probe the electrochemical properties for capacitive energy storage.
2. A roboust fabrication technique and simple surface functionalisation of Aerographite
with optimum porosity that provides high specific capacitance with high energy and power densities.
3. The macropores and micropores in the Aerographite are both generated during the
synthesis and template removal, which facilitates the addition of redox active functional groups.
4. The Aerographite electrodes show substantially improved capacitive performances.
Electrochemical
capacitors
Electrolytic capacitors
Fuel cells
5. The light-weight hybrid electrode materials could significantly accelerate developments
in the field of energy storage and provide versatile platforms for high-performance energy devices.

Aerographite nano-microtubular network material is a single step process in the chemical vapour deposition (CVD) and is mainly achieved via direct conversion of three dimensional porous sacrificial templates of tetrapodal zinc oxide (ZnO).[26, 32] Therefore it has got the flexibility of tailoring the bulk parameter like surface area and free volume by the assembly of the template.

In contrast to other carbon-based nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes and graphene, Aerographite exhibits smooth fracture behaviour with an ultimate tensile strength in the range of 1 to 100 kPa, which is higher than its counterparts.[26, 28, 32] All these outstanding physical and chemical features make Aerographite an ideal candidate to be explored for energy storage applications.

There are various instruments and test methods that have been used to characterize the performance of electrochemical capacitors.[9] Cyclic voltammetry (CV), constant current charge-discharge (CCCD), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) are the most commonly employed techniques.

used, accurate and versatile technique to characterize electrochemical capacitors under constant current.[36] The measurements are usually conducted by repetitive chargingdischarging of the capacitor device or the working electrode at a constant current.

Based on Bode and Nyquist plots, one can calculate capacitance and ESR, respectively.[37-38] The Figure 5A shows a Bode plot for the same data pictured in the Nyquist plot (Figure 5B) in open circuit potential.

metadata.abstractText: A great deal of interest has been paid to the application of carbon-based nanoand microstructured materials as electrodes due to their relatively low-cost production, abundance, large surface area, high chemical stability, wide operating temperature range, and ease of processing including many more excellent features. The nanostructured carbon materials usually offer various micro-textures due to their varying degrees of graphitisation, a rich variety in terms of dimensionality as well as morphologies, extremely large surface accessibility and high electrical conductivity, etc. The possibilities of activating them by chemical and physical methods allow these materials to be produced with further higher surface area and controlled distribution of pores from nanoscale upto macroscopic dimensions, which actually play the most crucial role towards construction of the efficient
metadata.creator: Elsevier
